repnme.cdata!: Viet Nam - Second Highway Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts, accomplished by satisfactory
            performances by the Bank and Borrower. Following are several
            lessons from the project experience. Enhancing institutional
            capacity of the recipient agency in several competencies -
            road maintenance, implementation of highway projects,
            traffic management, and road transport sector training
            systems - were project objectives, and an integral part of
            the project and the Credit Agreement. However, the Ministry
            of Transport (MOT) was reticent in approving technical
            assistance, only few activities were approved and
            implemented, and training only started at the later part of
            the project, therefore not achieving the institutional
            capacity building as planned. Rather, support to capacity
            building should only take place after careful consideration,
            and discussion with the agencies involved, its design should
            be well advanced during project preparation, including
            defined performance indicators, and intermediate results
            linked to project outcomes, with emphasis on government
            ownership. MOT needs to improve its ability to plan, budget
            and monitor maintenance activities, to facilitate
            preservation, and improve access for road users, taking into
            account its Ten-year Strategic Maintenance Plan, when
            preparing annual work programs. Other lessons address the
            need to strengthen the role of the Supervision Engineer;
            and, for design and construction standards consistent with
            project objectives, through planning and programming
            processes for road maintenance, further enhanced with
            capacity building and standards for maintenance works,
            adopted as a prerequisite for any future road maintenance
            program. It is highlighted that environmental and
            resettlement monitoring should be independent from the
            project, with a framework consistent with internationally
            recognized practices for design, implementation, and
            operation of road projects. Finally, and although for nearly
            a decade, restructuring and privatization of state-owned
            enterprises (SOEs) has been occurring, there is however the
            need for equity programs to improve the operational and
            financial performance of SOEs.

5078123.trustfund:
TF035190-VIETNAM - HIGHWAY REHAB. PROJECT,TF032832-ASIA- ENVIRONMENT(EAST &
            SOUTH ASIA),TF035102-VIETNAM - HIGHWAY
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF035191-VIETNAM - HIGHWAY
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF033668-VIETNAM - TRANSPORT,TF031100-VIETNAM - TRANSPORT,TF036278-VIETNAM - HIGHWAY
            REHABILITATION II AND III,TF033785-VIETNAM - SECOND HIGHWAY REHABILITATION,TF021251-PHRD-JAPANESE CTF (USD ACCOUNT),TF033028-VIETNAM - SECOND HIGHWAY REHAB. PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The broader developmental goal of the
            Second Highway Rehabilitation Project is to raise overall
            economic efficiency and support the country's economic
            and social development through an improved transport
            infrastructure.  The specific project objectives are: to
            reduce transport costs through improved national road
            infrastructure, particularly, Highway No. 1;  to enhance the
            efficiency by road sector institutions in periodic
            maintenance of the national road network; to reduce vehicle
            overloading and improve traffic safety; and to enhance the
            Ministry of Transport and Communications' institutional
            capacity in environmental impact assessment and monitoring.
            The project will comprise the following components:  (1)
            Road maintenance and rehabilitation -this includes
            reconstructing the Vinh-Dong Ha section of National Highway
            No. 1, reconstructing two major bridges at Chanh Hoa and
            Quan Hau; acquiring land, resettling and rehabilitating
            project-affected people, and providing supervision
            consultant services;  (2) Periodic maintenance of selected
            priority national roads -this aims at systematic, periodic
            maintenance of national highways by contract, and
            implementation of the new road maintenance management system
            being developed under the on-going first highway
            rehabilitation project;  (3)   Improvement of hazardous road
            sections -selected critical sections of national highways
            will be improved based on the Vietnam Road Safety
            Improvement Study made under the first highway
            rehabilitation project, and will include measures to improve
            traffic safety like providing adequate road furniture,
            signs, and traffic management facilities;  (4) Support to
            the Project Management Unit for Highway No. 1 (PMU1) -this
            will further enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of
            PMU1 to manage highway projects by purchasing vehicles and
            office equipment, construct an operating center, and give
            technical support for project implementation, monitoring and
            evaluation functions, operation cost, staff training, and
            support for environmental impact assessment;  (5) Support to
            the Vietnam Road Administration (VRA) and the Regional Road
            Management Unions (RRMU) -this will enhance institutional
            capacity by providing additional maintenance equipment for
            RRMUs and axle load weighing stations and equipment for VRA;
            (6) Training -this will train the trainers for the transport
            sector training system, strengthen local institutions, and
            enhance the skills of highway sector manpower;   (7)
            Detailed design and engineering studies -this includes the
            design and engineering study of two road sections and
            detailed design and preparation of bid documents for future
            periodic maintenance components.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Second Highway Rehabilitation
            Project (HRP 2) - environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Second Highway Rehabilitation Project (HRP2) in
            Indonesia, which improves the national road infrastructure.
            Persons displaced by land or house acquisition will receive
            compensation, relocation, and/or rehabilitation according to
            the resettlement action plan. All trees, saplings, and
            shrubbery will be protected from unnecessary damage.
            Thereafter, reseeding, replanting, or restoration will
            prevent further damage (i.e. erosion) and restore
            quasi-original conditions. After their use, borrow pits and
            other material resource areas will be landscaped and planted
            to provide substitute areas for displaced natural habitats
            or other appropriate land use. Wastewater will be treated by
            using settling ponds, gravel filters, or other processes so
            as not to impair water quality or harm aquatic life. Dust
            from vehicles or equipment will be minimized by regularly
            sprinkling water or other acceptable methods. Waste
            materials, brush, or trees will be burned only under
            favorable weather conditions. To minimize traffic delays and
            to protect pedestrians along work areas, temporary access
            will be provided to residents.  Construction activities will
            be limited to daytime hours.  Noise, from blasting, hauling,
            and other such operations will be minimized by using
            low-noise machines. Route and timing of material transport
            will be carefully selected to minimize impacts on schools,
            hospitals, and environmentally sensitive facilities.

docna.cdata!:
Vietnam - Second Highway Rehabilitation
            Project (HRP 2) - environmental impact assessment
